Banking-as-a-Service (BaaS) and Open Banking may seem similar, but in reality, there is a distinct difference between the two models. Open Banking provides access to customer data from banks, while BaaS goes further, allowing third parties to access banking functions and services. Therefore, BaaS not only incorporates the features of Open Banking but also integrates the banking API platform, creating a more diverse and powerful financial services ecosystem.
Why is BaaS the best solution?

The banking industry and the very meaning of being a bank are changing. As digital channels become more prevalent in every aspect of life—from entertainment, shopping, to even booking medical appointments—consumer expectations are also shifting toward seamless, fast, and convenient experiences. This transformation requires banks to adapt and meet increasingly higher customer experience demands, thereby creating sustainable competitive advantages in the digital era.

A recent study by Galileo in collaboration with American Banker revealed that 78% of senior bank executives are currently prioritizing the development of Banking-as-a-Service (BaaS) capabilities. Notably, 59% of the banks focusing on BaaS have at least entered the trial stage, highlighting the strong transformation of the industry in integrating innovative banking service solutions.

Traditional banks with technological advantages can mitigate the threat of fintech by engaging in the BaaS industry to share their data and infrastructure. Instead of competing, collaboration is the key to a successful banking strategy. Furthermore, BaaS platforms enhance financial transparency by allowing banks to open their APIs to third parties to develop new services.

BaaS also provides banks with deeper customer insights by identifying customer financial needs and purchasing behaviors, which financial institutions can leverage to create personalized offers for their clients. Unsurprisingly, 80% of banking customers respond positively to personalized offers.

Open Banking Platforms and APIs

BaaS and APIs go hand in hand, even when it comes to data operations. This function is essential for organizing, mapping, or transforming data before sending it to the backend, ultimately presented to customers.

Banks intend to expand API usage to reduce IT complexity, boost agility, and empower partners. BaaS features a modular architecture that combines manageable functionality with drag-and-drop simplicity, streamlining complex backend operations for developers.

APIs provide applications with a new level of modularity. APIs allow developers to leverage the expertise of other programs. When a company builds an application, it no longer has to reinvent the wheel in areas such as authentication, communication, payment processing, and mapping. Instead, developers can use the seamless plug-in functionality of APIs. APIs enable applications and system components to connect with each other across both intranets and the Internet.

Benefits of Open Banking APIs include:

  1. Attracting and retaining customers: Banks can reach new potential customers more effectively and at lower costs.

  2. New revenue streams: Banks charge non-bank partners for each API transaction.

  3. Modernizing technology functions: More flexible and agile banking systems accelerate product development.

The Future of BaaS Banking

Banking-as-a-Service (BaaS), APIs, and Open Banking all revolve around a core concept: granting third-party access to banks’ data and credentials. This not only creates new products but also enhances consumer experiences. BaaS allows third parties to leverage banks’ capabilities through the use of APIs and Open Banking.

All these approaches have reshaped the traditional banking landscape, opening opportunities for both banks and non-bank enterprises to strengthen competitiveness and maximize profitability.
